name: Green Tea Extract
summary: Green tea extract, rich in catechins such as EGCG, is studied for its antioxidant, metabolic, and neuroprotective properties, with potential benefits in mood, cognition, and weight regulation.
description: Green tea extract is derived from the leaves of Camellia sinensis and contains concentrated polyphenols, particularly epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG). These bioactive compounds exert strong antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects, modulate neurotransmitter activity, and improve metabolic function. Green tea extract has been investigated for its potential in supporting cognitive health, reducing stress and anxiety, and promoting weight management. It is commonly used in integrative and preventive medicine for its cardiometabolic and neuroprotective benefits.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for specific medical conditions)

off_label_uses: Adjunctive support for anxiety and stress
contraindications: Liver disease (rare hepatotoxicity at high doses)
Sensitivity to caffeine (though extract is often decaffeinated)
monitoring_required: Liver enzymes with high-dose or long-term use

items: May aid in weight management and metabolic regulation
Potential neuroprotective effects for cognition and memory
Adjunctive support for stress and anxiety reduction

sections.text: Green tea extract is rich in catechins, particularly epigallocatechin gallate (EGCG), which acts as a powerful antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent. It modulates neurotransmitter activity by influencing GABA, dopamine, and norepinephrine signaling, contributing to stress reduction and cognitive support. EGCG also promotes fat oxidation, enhances endothelial function, and may reduce neuroinflammation.

adult.note: Higher doses (up to 800 mg/day EGCG) have been used in clinical trials but increase risk of hepatotoxicity.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; insufficient safety data.

sections.text: Metabolic and antioxidant effects may be seen within weeks; cognitive and mood benefits may require longer supplementation.

other: May cause liver injury at high doses; monitor liver function.
Caffeine-containing extracts may cause insomnia, anxiety, or palpitations in sensitive individuals.

items: Liver enzymes with prolonged or high-dose use

sections.pregnancy: Caution; avoid high doses due to caffeine content and limited safety data
sections.lactation: Caffeine may pass into breast milk; use decaffeinated extract if necessary
sections.pediatrics: Not recommended due to limited data
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe at moderate doses; monitor for liver and cardiovascular effects

sections.text: No taper required; can discontinue abruptly without withdrawal.

items: Decaffeinated extracts are generally preferred in psychiatry-focused use.
Evidence strongest for metabolic and cardiovascular support; cognitive and psychiatric effects are less established.
High-dose EGCG (>800 mg/day) associated with rare cases of hepatotoxicity.
